They then took the shape of a hungry ghost who had eaten and vomited.
He was beside the corpse.
The good star went into the cold forest.
He saw the body of the suffering victim.
The good star said.
"Is the great virtuous man dead?
He replied, "I've already died.
"I've already died.
How did I die?
He replied.
'I died of abdominal pain.'
Who will release your corpse?
He replied.
"Fellow student!
Where will you put it?
He replied, "Foolish man!
'Don't you now realize this is the cold forest?'
What kind of body has it attained?
He replied.
'I've got the body of a food-spitting ghost.'
Sun-Sung said.
"Bhagavān!
'Suffering will get me born in the Trāyastriṃśa Heaven as a Nirgrantha.'
I said, 'Foolish man!'
'There's no place for an arhat to be born.'
How can you say that?
Suffering obtains birth in the Trāyastriṃśa Heaven.
The Tathāgata and Kāśyapa went there.
They went to the good star.
The good star saw from a distance that a bad, mistaken mind had arisen.
He's born in a body that's plunged into the avīci hell.
It's like a person who's submerged in a toilet.
A good teacher puts his hand over it and scratches it.
If he gets his head of hair, he wants to pull it out.
After a long time, he can't get it out.
Then, he stops thinking.
'I'm likewise.
I seek out a good star with few good roots.
I then want to pull it out and rescue it.
I spent my whole day searching for it.
I couldn't get as little as a hair.

source_sentence: 是故不得拔其地獄(出大涅槃經第三十七卷)。
translation: Therefore, I couldn't uproot it from hell (from the thirty-seventh roll of the Mahāparinirvāṇa-sūtra).
